I recently experienced a panic response due to my OCD. The feeling came on after feeling no fear all day so I thought I was doing fine. Its incredible how visceral the feeling is. Panic is the best way to describe it. Its so bizarre how realistic the thought feels. It feels like dread, panic, and fear all at once. Its calling me to take action and to think the problem away. Im currently smiling in the face of this fear because I realized that this fear is just like any other ailment. This fear is a symptom of OCD. By distancing myself from this fear and calling it a symptom, I am able to have more clarity now. Its so interesting how my brain argues against it just being a symptom as well. My brain wants so much to believe that this panic is reality and that I am justly afraid and that I should be afraid.The more I think about it, OCD is just a very convincing salesman that borders on coercion. No matter how you try to argue with OCD, it seems to always come back with an incredibly good argument to reel you back in.

So Ive made some progress with my OCD lately. I managed to separate my rituals into concrete ones - regarding my fear of flying or getting injured, for example. And abstract - the rituals that I do out of habit, created over many years of OCD. Then I noticed that most of my rituals are abstract and its much easier for me to resist those, since there is no particular fear attached.However what I struggle with is resisting these abstract rituals that cause a thoughtless mental discomfort. And while Im okay with not doing a ritual I cant revert (e.g. throwing out the trash in the wrong way - I usually cant redo that, so luckily my mind just lets it go), sometimes it is possible to redo an action.As an example - I was playing a single player computer game and I did something the wrong way in it. Sure, I thought, I want to resist redoing and kept playing. However after three(!) days of playing I couldnt get rid of this mental discomfort of doing something the wrong way. The entire time I was anxious and full of doubt that Id need to reload from before doing that action and lose 3 days of progress. That made every game session not enjoyable at all. I ended up doing a substitution ritual to somehow alleviate that discomfort. However losing to OCD made it worse, now every time I play any game, I need to do everything the correct way, otherwise Im afraid Ill get this mental discomfort again and will need to reload and lose progress or do a more severe OCD ritual.How do you deal with that?

Sorry if I am rambling. Was just trying to get this all out right after it happened.

I hope this can help somebody.

How do you guys accept OCD? Not just having it, but accepting the fact youve had to deal with it.I have been an obsessive person my entire life (I think it may be autism-related), and when I was 4 or 5 I started having obsessive fears that I would do things to protect myself from. I started having serious intrusive thoughts around the time I was 10 which is about when the rituals started as well. The point is, I havent known much of a life without unwanted thoughts parading in. I specifically remember being 11 and having a brilliant day at my grandparents, and then remembering something sinful/God offending I did many months before (that I had already confessed, mind you) and feeling sick to my stomach, and feeling the need to confess immediately.  This was a reoccurring event, having a day or moment ruined by intrusive thoughts. It has affected my relationships with just about everyone in my life . I have lost so much time and mental (and in some cases physical) energy to whatever the hell OCD  is and I just feel,, angry. Usually, I try to go about life with a sort of nothing is wasted attitude (partially because I am terrified of having regrets when I die, another intrusive thought...) but thats just what OCD seems like, a waste.I guess I just wanted to rant but I also want advice, how do yall do it?

Long story short Im a 21(f) who lives in Australia. I started hormonal birth control at 17 which lead to a spiral into serious ocd that despite bouncing from therapist to doctor and back, had never been properly treated until the past 3 months (exposure therapy ect. with a an ocd specialist). I am currently on a medication (Mirtazapine) that I am working towards stopping as it has done nothing for me mentally and was prescribed by an uniformed gp at a hospital vist. For the first time since since prior to the birth control I am feeling confident, healthy and totally in control even while constantly lowering my meds with my gp. However with this comes feeling entirely unfulfilled, Im a professional photographer progressing quickly through my career (manager in 2 months with opportunities for bigger roles almost immediately). But along side my mental health spiral came me giving up on my dream careers as they are all ADF based. I have no doubt I could succeed in other areas of entry (and even despite my own internal struggle with anxiety its never been induced by high stress environments, its always hightend by long streches of inactivity and boredem such as in covid and Ive been mentally at my best in fast paced jobs) I just am almost certain that my history would automatically exclude me.The roles I am looking at specifically are Air Force intelligence and signals based roles. Spending the next few years working on getting medication free and entirely self managed/in remission is my goal regardless, it would just be a nice cherry on top to land my dream career.Any insight would be great cause I am a little bit hopeless regarding this.

Hey yall!I just got the results from an ADHD assessment I took earlier this month (ADHD-PI, super excited!) and they tested me for a variety of other things to eliminate any possible overlapping symptoms--including OCD.I was diagnosed with OCD at about nine or ten years old, with a particular trend for moral scrupulosity and contamination-based obsessions. It was extremely debilitating and it feels sometimes that I was cheated out of a proper childhood, but Ive been on Zoloft since about 2020, and Ive been managing my symptoms better than I ever imagined I could. I havent indulged in an obsession for more than ten minutes for about two years, Id say. I still have intrusive thoughts and repetitive behaviors, but I can easily brush them off and even laugh at them. *Laugh* at them!So they did a subtest for OCD behaviors and symptoms, and they decided that I present as Other Specified Obsessive Compulsive Disorder. Basically, my OCD is barely recognizable now that Im on the medication and have been utilizing proper coping methods.Im just incredibly grateful. I never thought Id ever get to this point!

i don‚Äôt trust my own opinions on things, and anything that people say plagues me with extreme doubt. it doesn‚Äôt matter who they are, even if i hate them i mull over what they say to prove they‚Äôre incorrect or that my opinions are sound and well informed. to reassure myself i seek out people who agree with me, but i hate that i need to have my opinions validated by others to feel okay with having them (the ‚Äòokay‚Äô feeling is short lived too). it‚Äôs embarrassing to cry over a 2 word comment with 5 likes from years ago. i hate how much power other people‚Äôs words have on me due to ocd. it makes me feel like a sensitive child with a victim complex‚Ä¶i don‚Äôt even think what i have is moral ocd, because the source of my distress isn‚Äôt being a ‚Äògood‚Äô or ‚Äòbad‚Äô person‚Ä¶ its more like, a feeling of disgust, anger or annoyance at seeing something i disagree with or dislike to the point where i have to ritualistically justify my own stance otherwise i agree with it, or must believe it is correct if i can‚Äôt counter it properly‚Ä¶ my ocd hit a new low yesterday, when i felt disgust with myself because i smiled for the sake of being polite to i person i heavily disliked and disagreed with‚Ä¶ i literally had to reassure myself that i smiled out of politeness, not because i agreed with them‚Ä¶

So I have this thing where basically OCD doesnt allow me to have secrets/privacy. And normally, I could accept this. Ive kind of grown used to it over the years. The problem? It doesnt allow me to be a confidant either. If somebody tells me something private or thats a secret, my brain instantly goes into anxiety mode until I can confess whatever it is to somebody else. It even does this for stuff that, while wasnt stated as a secret or privacy, if I KNOW better than to reveal it, it still counts.​This has tortured me for years, actually leading to suicidal thoughts on multiple occasions because I couldnt cope. I just cant seem to beat this no matter how hard I try. My longest at resisting it was 3 years and it haunted me, I only got release because the person themselves ended up revealing the information.I dont know what to do. No, I cant usually post whatever it is online anonymously. Im a tad desperate.

I am going deep with therapeutic advice to find the root. My style of dealing with things in life is to discover the root cause of things. And because of this i just had a very helfful revelation of relief.We have intrusive thoughts that cause pain and distress but interestingly enough i need physiotherapy and during that they discovered that my deepr muscles had always been like stone and that i need a lot of physiotherapy to get back into shape meaning negative thoughts sometimes are caused by the pain and distress caused by a lack of movement and body activity in the past.​But well whatever the answer is. It is still an interesting question: Do our thoughts cause the pain and distress or does the pain and the distress cause the negative thoughts? Because healthy people have these negative thoughts as well however with them they can push these negative thoughts away or they can remove stress by distracting themselves with hobbies also prayer works well with them. ​Anyway like really interesting question that kinda made things less worse now because there is always a root cause and finding that root is to me the goal. Of course i continue with daily life but i have a notebook where i take notes when i make progress with my OCD recovery because i have faith that i can heal myself fully by introspection.

What it says on the tin. I had my first ERP session this week and let me tell you it was brutal. I was curled up in the fetal position afterward; Im not totally sure my therapist knew what to do. She says things like Im so brave and Im facing my fears but I dont think I actually have the self-esteem to believe it. My OCD is a bully, it tells me that Im a shit woman, that Im not beautiful or successful or good enough, and that I should just give up and be a man because clearly Ive failed so hard at being a woman. And you know what? I believe it. Im not pretty. Im undateable. I grew up in a small town and waited my whole life to come to the big city and meet other lesbians but when I did they were so much cooler and more put together and well-adjusted and definitely had less internalized homophobia than me. I felt like a freak, like everyone knew what they were doing and how to talk and how to act and I didnt. When I see someone being put down, I step in and defend them no problem. But when I get bullied, either by my brain or in real life, I fold like a house of cards. So when my OCD is like look at your life, would you define that as success? youre ugly and no one wants you, and no one is gonna wanna deal with your internalized homophobia and trauma. You should just cut your losses and start over as a man, I dont have an argument against that, even though the thought of being a man instead of a woman elicits the same feeling in me of having my skull crushed by a train.

I have always been very anxious about people taking or going on my phone. I‚Äôm still anxious about it when my boyfriend of three years will try to open my phone (he knows the password). For a while I have been struggling with thoughts about me cheating on him, since I don‚Äôt let him go on my phone, I see that behavior in myself and I start to think‚Ä¶ am I doing this because I know I‚Äôm guilty? (Spoiler alert: I haven‚Äôt cheated, nothing to find on my phone)This morning though I realized something. When I was a young kid and first got a phone (I‚Äôm 20 so I got a phone in 4th grade), my mom would randomly take it and search through my browser history, photo gallery, and text messages, and would confront me about anything she found that she thought was strange. There were multiple times where she would find either some corny boyband tumblr screenshots in my camera roll, or she would find fan fiction in my browser history, and she would hold it over my head for months. She would just bring it up in casual conversation to humiliate me in front of friends/family, or bring it up when we were alone to bully me.After that, I became fiercely protective of my phone, and would delete every single possible thing that could be potentially embarrassing. Out of fear of being humiliated again. They say an OCD diagnosis can sometimes be a symptom of CPTSD, and I‚Äôm really seeing that now as I go back and look at my childhood. It‚Äôs wild

I know a lot of the autism community is really supportive of it for a variety of reasons (though not everyone) but how do people here feel about that? The autism/adhd diagnosis was more a cognitive test and I havent managed really to talk openly to anyone about complex mental health speifics or get myself to figure out how to meet with someone who even could diagnose mental health conditions that involve discussing any degree of nuance. I feel personally very confident that I not only have OCD as a 31 year old adult but have since I was an extremely young child and pretty clearly remember a lot of my early struggles with it. Also not just for my case but more broadly what are your thoughts on self identifying what you are going through and tryng to go from there?

So I‚Äôve been trying to apply the method of Dr. Michael Greenberg regarding my OCD to stop ruminating. But it feels easier said than done. Whenever I try, it feels as if I‚Äôm starting to block the thoughts. Let‚Äôs say, something popped up in my head that caused anxiety or some painful reaction, so I‚Äôm trying not to think about it basically. Like I am trying not to ruminate about it, but in the end the whole thought process is being stopped and I‚Äôm wandering with a blank mind for a while. Then I get urges to check what‚Äôs up in my mind or what‚Äôs bothering me, and I‚Äôm trying not to give into them. However, I start to feel a strong resistance. And I also don‚Äôt know what to think about, it feels like every thought is an OCD thought. So, in a nutshell, it feels like I‚Äôm doing something wrong, as if I‚Äôm suppressing the thoughts or suppressing the emotions, or even both. What‚Äôs also confusing for me that Dr. Greenberg said in his articles that when you stop ruminating, if you‚Äôre doing it right, your anxiety diminishes almost instantly. Which happens, but for a brief period of time, until I feel resistance in the body. Or maybe I‚Äôm getting something wrong? In the end, what is bothering me the most about trying not to ruminate, or not to think anything, is that my neck and my temple muscles become extremely tense, creating physical pain. It‚Äôs especially uncomfortable during the night, when I‚Äôm trying to fall asleep. And as far as I understand, this is a psychosomatic symptom, which means I‚Äôm probably blocking a thought or an emotion, which creates tension headache. Any advice on how to improve non-ruminating technique or on what I might be doing wrong?

It‚Äôs not really that I think something bad will happen if I don‚Äôt maximize efficiency, I just feel really uncomfortable and stuck, and have a harder time avoiding ruminating if I don‚Äôt. I mainly have ‚Äújust right‚Äù thoughts/compulsions. It makes change really difficult. I almost had a meltdown today at work because we had a slight change in process that made the process feel wrong just because it was a little different üôÑBut the more I reflect on what areas of my life have been impacted by OCD, I think that I have an obsession with efficiency. Making an egg sandwich? Gotta start cooking the egg right when I put the bread in the toaster and make sure I flip the bread exactly when I put the cheese so it‚Äôs all ready at the same time. Making coffee in the morning? Gotta heat up the water and then draw all the curtains and get the dog his water bowl or I won‚Äôt be able to relax with my coffee. Working on a project at work? Need to do things in exactly the right order because I know it‚Äôs the most efficient way to do it. Definitely cannot adapt to less efficient ways of doing things/methods that take my control over the efficiency away. I don‚Äôt even ruminate about any lack of efficiency‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll ruminate about other things affected by the lack of efficiency.

I would put multiple flairs on this if possible. I hope this doesn‚Äôt come off as seeking reassurance, but it was simply an aspect of OCD that I was super curious about.I was diagnosed a few months ago, and since then i‚Äôve been doing some deeper diving into how my OCD relates into specific personality traits i‚Äôve had for years. I‚Äôm short, I feel a sort of mental health imposter syndrome. I see all different sorts of descriptions of OCD, and the moment something doesn‚Äôt apply to me, I think I‚Äôm a liar who‚Äôs making it up and exaggerating. I VERY OFTEN feel as if other people‚Äôs OCD is much worse than mine and that mine is more a manageable and that I don‚Äôt deserve to say that I have OCD because it‚Äôs not to the same degree as others and that i‚Äôm supposed to be struggling more.I‚Äôm also a very internally paranoid person, but with no visible compulsions or outward manifestations of reassurance seeking, which also seems like it‚Äôs not a real thing I suffer with. Lastly, masochism. I tend to have self-sabotaging and people-pleasing tendencies, having also grown up in an emotionally/physically abusive relationship with my parents has created an unhealthy attachment style, ruining my relationships. I guess my question is, has anyone else experienced this OR is there any correlation or scientific research to back up a connection between OCD and these traits?

I dont really know where else to post this for some solid advice, so here goes.I have a friend that is really starting to irk me.  We have a lot of classes together and get to work together a lot, or at least in the same vicinity of each other, so i see her a lot.  She tends to bring up feeling very OCD at times, typically when something isnt made neat within a project.  I know that order can be a part of OCD, and i dont want to sound like a horrible person, but i dont believe that she really has OCD, or that she even understands what it truely is.  Ive asked her about her diagnosis history (shes really open about it) and she said shes never been diagnosed.I know that self diagnosing exists, and i know that it can lead to a future diagnosis, but its just the way that she says it.  Its like she thinks its funny.  Shes like oh im so OCD and those pencils being askew is really messing with me or this wooden plaque my bf made me and my OCD hates it.  Its just so hard for me to believe that she does actually have it.  I dont even know if she believes it.  I know some of her behaviors could be OCD diagnostic criteria, and i dont want to invalidate her experiences, it just bothers me.  I have family and friends who have struggled with it.  Ive had the ability to chat with people actually diagnosed with it.  I am not an expert, and i probably wont ever know what its really like to struggle with OCD, but it just feels like shes making fun of something that has drastically impacted the way people i love even think.How do i bring this up to her in a way that is still respectable?  I dont want her to think im trying to accuse her of anything, im not.  I dont wanna be insensitive, because maybe she really does have it.  I just wanna convey that the way she uses OCD makes it sound like shes making fun of it.Maybe im making too big a deal of it.  I dont have OCD, and i could be invalidating her experiences and im just being an asshole.  It just feels weird the way she uses it.

Like most here, I suffer with intrusive thoughts and ridiculous compulsions.It‚Äôs immeasurably affected my life. When I start to feel upset, all my motivation leaves me. It makes me not want to do anything.Something similar is say I go through the first 3 days off the week being very productive and following my schedule. Then the 4th I feel shitty mentally so I don‚Äôt end up doing anything. I automatically negate the entire week and don‚Äôt feel good or proud about ANYTHING I‚Äôve done. I have an obsession with my schedule being perfect or things going just the way I plan. Friends, I wanna share my history of coping with OCD. I‚Äôm 23, F and suffered from ocd since I was 16 years old, including 2 yrs of bulimia. Recently I had catastrophic relapse and spent days being totally paralysed, ruminating, obsessing about even simple things, lost weight, control, capability to work. Constant anxiety, obsessions, and secondary depression. Now I‚Äôm in CBT and at SSRI for almost 6 months and can surely say that CBT saved me. Now preparing to transcranial magnetic stimulation to affect the biological reason as my ocd is mostly hereditary. I wanna share some tips which may sound a little bit banal but they really work:
  • practice self-compassion, hug yourself, say how you love yourself no matter what, looking at the mirror.
  • NEVER engage into your obsessions. During obsessive episode your cognition is distorted. Be at the initial stage and stay here no matter how you are anxious, try to form a thought about your thought.
  • practice exposure, try to tolerate anxiety, it will pass and each time your brain will receive new experience
  • engage yourself in daily activities, make a schedule doing simple tasks and be sincerely grateful
  • communicate, tell about your disorder, laugh at your fears
  • have meals in the morning (especially), hunger in the first part of the day feeds your anxiety
  • avoid triggers (eg from family) and don‚Äôt seek support where you can‚Äôt get it even if you want to
  • practice mindfulness
  • two steps forward, one step back. Accept your failures in dealing with obsessions
I‚Äôm still not in complete recovery, but found ways how to live my life with obsessions, even if sometimes it‚Äôs unbearable I just let them come and go away not affecting behaviour. Remember you‚Äôre not alone and each obsession has its beginning and ending

I was always afraid of Adderall because people would tell me stories of taking it before a big test/project, and ‚Äúrunning 10 miles‚Äù or ‚Äúcleaning their whole house‚Äù instead. I thought Adderall made people obsessive or compulsive. Never considered my proclivity to ‚Äúdaydream‚Äù on one topic for hours and hours on end while not allowing myself to go pee even though my bladder was hurting because of some sort of ominous undertone to ‚Äúnot finishing exploring this thought‚Äù as, perhaps, o or c. Ever since I started adderall, what I thought was really bad anxiety, was just really bad obsessive thought spirals. When I take my adderall, it‚Äôs like, my thoughts are better lined up in a row. I still have a bad habit of not peeing/ diverting from a moment, but the time I spend trapped is, so much less. It feels like I actually have arms and eyes to climb out of the spiral (or to realize I literally just can side step it). It‚Äôs so weird. The relative calm and quiet (even when nothing in my reality actually warrants it at the moment). I‚Äôm better able to notice my anxious feelings, and even commit to healthier actions to alleviate it. Nothing is perfect, things are still hard, but these glimpses of ‚Äúnormalcy‚Äù add so much clarity to identifying abnormal moments (that I previously accepted as fine). Never what I expected Adderall to be like. Just sharing in a moment of, relief and awe.

I‚Äôm a conscious dreamer. I can leave whenever I am too overwhelmed, can identify my senses, become aware of when I‚Äôm dreaming, and observe them to absorb meanings and messages. Lately, I‚Äôve been trying to hold off on leaving immediately in my dreams when situations that highlight my OCD appear. At first I thought, they were to trigger me, like a nightmare, but now I think they are teaching me to observe and sit through it. My last dream, I was in my school cafeteria and was eating and realized my food was sitting bare on the table and before I could get overwhelmed, a girl sat across from me and we started talking and it took mymind off it rather and allowed me to overlook it. It was like exposure therapy that I haven‚Äôt been willing to do in my waking life. Challenge yourself to be uncomfortable for just a moment. Sit with the thoughts and obsessions and ask yourself how and why you feel the way you do. Replace them with something that dissolves them or distracts you from focusing on it, alone. Reassure yourself that it is okay for you to not give in to it and that you are still deserving of relieving yourself of the guilt of it. When you‚Äôre easier on yourself, I feel this is something that gets easier to deal with.

Hi all, this has been said to me by professionals but I‚Äôve also seen it on here as well. I just wanted to know the communities thoughts because I think some of my OCD tendencies is fixed on identity (like some types seem to to be I‚Äôve noticed).Thoughts not ‚Äúbeing me‚Äù is confusing to me, I still find it comfortable and helpful, but I don‚Äôt think I understand it fundamentally.I even try to think of it through the lense of mindfulness, how it can be suggested that to find relaxation one must ‚Äúlet go of the thoughts‚Äù or ‚Äúlet them run their course‚Äù. So, when people say you aren‚Äôt your thoughts, I can see how thoughts can be just a byproduct of the brain, but don‚Äôt necessarily inform of the nature of the brain (or yourself/beliefs/personality/etc.).Am I getting at it correctly? Does anybody else have a more simple, concrete view or explanation?I am often met with people who don‚Äôt have OCD saying to just think of something else or ignore them, but I feel like it may be hard for us because the thoughts feels as though they come from within, rather than just being produced because that‚Äôs what brains do (which I think people without OCD have an easier time separating themselves from the things that they happen to think about), and this can lead to turmoil and spiraling.If thoughts just feel random, they feel less like you. But when they are relentless and distressing, even if you fundamentally or logically understand they don‚Äôt reflect you, I feel like OCD can be parasitic in that it leeches the compartmentalizing energy and replaces with fear and obsession. It feeds on the anxiety like a positive Feedback loop, more thoughts cause more fear and therefore less fortitude in one‚Äôs identity to dismiss the thoughts as just thoughts. I wonder if what I‚Äôm getting at is clear, and I‚Äôm super curious to see what you all‚Äôs take on this is.

I dunno what it is called, so I call it a theme cycle for now. I will obsess over one theme, snap out of it, be fine for a while, be it a few minutes or a few hours, and then I will be stressing about another theme. And that even if I have a main theme I am always stressing about in the background. Today, I am not sure how to explain it, but I was at the swimming pool for four hours, I did not do anything in there, so my mind wandered, and I cycled through four themes. All while checking for my main theme every once in a while (that is almost a reflex by now). Now I am out and writing this, and I am feeling better.Do any of you relate? Or is it just me?

Hey all! I struggle with obsessive thinking and intrusive images. I never knew I had OCD until I finally asked my therapist about it when it reared its head immediately after giving birth to my first child. Nearly 3 years and another baby later, Ive done lots of therapy work (also, many thanks to Brain Lock), andIve got somewhat of a hold on it. The obsessive thinking and intrusive images still pop up, and Ive accepted them but I feel much more control in processing through them and coming back to the moment. No easy feat, thats for sure. But every now and then, they show up in the middle of the night (between 2-3am) and it feels like all the skills I learned go right out the window and I struggle so hard to get through them. Before I know it, 2-3 hours have passed and Im still ruminating on thoughts that have consumed me. When I finally fall asleep, I wake up for the morning and have the same thoughts, but am able to get through them. Typically this happens after some sort of an event that triggers internal trauma. Im assuming I have a hard time at night because my brain isnt fully awake(?), or Im just too mentally tired to successfully process these thoughts(?). A reminder, I have 2 kids under the age of 3, which means rest during the day is a pipe dream. My number one priority  is being as present and sound as possible for my kids. As we all know, diminished sleep only exasperates OCD so Im trying to get ahead of a vicious cycle that may be looming. Does anyone have any similar experiences or tips theyd be willing share? Many thanks.

Hello,I see my doctor in a month, and I‚Äôve had a small suspicion that I am showing some signs of OCD. I get these thoughts (not going into detail) that cause me immense amounts of anxiety and the only way the anxiety goes away is if I find something to satisfy my mind. (Ex: I worry about my cat running away while I‚Äôm not home, so I research missing/found local cats. If I don‚Äôt see my cat, I can relax because my mind has found an answer). I did not realize this was uncommon until some coworkers pointed out my behaviors. Obviously I don‚Äôt worry about losing my cat, but that‚Äôs the best example I can give without being graphic. I don‚Äôt do any ritualistic behaviors though. I don‚Äôt do the stereotypical over-washing my hands or organization. I just think too much, imagine scenarios and then have a panic attack thinking my imagined scenario is going to happen. I‚Äôm already diagnosed with depression and anxiety, but my anxiety is getting to the point where every day I‚Äôm a worrying mess. These panic attacks will cause me to be so depressed for days. To the point where I can‚Äôt get out of bed because I‚Äôm worrying so much and so depressed about it. I‚Äôve called into work because I cannot function with the anxiety. One of my parents has OCD and GAD. My grandmother also has OCD. Along with many, many other family members who are clinically diagnosed with OCD, anxiety and bipolar 2. I want to bring this up to my doctor, but I don‚Äôt want to look like the usual young person who saw something on TikTok and is self diagnosing (I don‚Äôt even have TikTok). I just genuinely want to know so I can make the thoughts and anxiety stop. Also, so I can start the right therapy/meds.I don‚Äôt know how to bring it up to him or what to say about it.

I know it‚Äôs nonsense but I caught myself doing this when I‚Äôve managed to reduce all my other compulsions, is it sneaky reassurance seeking or just a weird brain? I‚Äôm not sure.

the past couple of months, I‚Äôve been dealing with these ‚Äúmemories‚Äù (not entirely sure if they‚Äôre real or not) of stuff I supposedly did as a kid, around 11 or 12. That was around 10 years ago. Which is making me question whether or not they‚Äôre true. About 4 years ago, I had a really bad bout of OCD, I‚Äôve dealt with it most of my life but this moment was the time I had actually been diagnosed. I could barely eat, sleep or just function normally. I was able to have these worries fact checked and that helped a bit after a while, it still lasted a few months.
These new memories are completely different but have the same theme as the ones before. Which makes me question, why didn‚Äôt they appear 4 years ago, during that bad episode? Why now, about 10 years after supposedly happening?
I have no memory of thinking/worrying about these memories until a couple of months ago. I don‚Äôt want to go into detail about what these ‚Äúmemories‚Äù are but they are not something I would just forget and not care about. I deal with incredible guilt over everything. I accidentally killed a spider last week, and despite my fear and dislike for them, I felt bad. Which makes it seem so out of character that I would do the things in these memories and ignore/ forget about them and not care.
Part of me is worried that I‚Äôm only entertaining the idea that they are fake memories to get away with it and not have to deal with the guilt. It‚Äôs like I‚Äôm in denial and they actually are true.
The memories feel sort of dream like, and not like my actual memories but what if I‚Äôm just making myself feel that way?I know there‚Äôs virtually no way to distinguish between a false memory but I‚Äôm stuck right now. I‚Äôm holding myself back in case they‚Äôre true. I don‚Äôt know how to fix it

I have contamination OCD, mostly stemmed from my parents extreme religious behavior. I can‚Äôt look at statues or figurines of god/deities because it makes me feel disgusted and I can‚Äôt get the pictures out of my head. On top of that, because I grew up around so many people constantly praying and doing weird shit I feel that everything is contaminated by the germs from those statues that people touch and basically that‚Äôs where the contamination part comes from too. Now I think everything is dirty except for the things that I specifically keep clean (mostly in my room). I can‚Äôt touch anyone, anything that belongs to someone else including pets. I don‚Äôt let people touch my things or coke in my room. If I have to go out I know I will ‚Äúget dirty‚Äù and that doesn‚Äôt bother me because when I come home, I clean my phone with very strong alcohol, I shower and clean my entire body with soap. That‚Äôs not the worst part though. Everytime I, for example drink water or go to the bathroom, I have to wash my hands and arms and that can take a minimum of 5 min to a max of 15 on average (30 min washing one time :<sup>}).</sup> Anyways when I feel microsensations on my skin I have to wash that area too. Literally half an hour ago I went to take a piss and I felt a micro sensation on my neck and I knew I had to wash that area but I couldn‚Äôt properly so I had to shower and my skin is bleeding from the soap use. I‚Äôm so tired of living with this shit. Everyday it‚Äôs the same battle and no one understands. I just want it to end like my life at this point.
I‚Äôm so sick of doing this. I was supposed to go to the gym, do chores and get some uni work done.I‚Äôm afraid of looking back over my life and seeing so many wasted days.

The only time I did a manicure was when I was young, or maybe once in a blue moon, ie. going on holiday etc. Subsequently, I was working backend in the F n B industry hence I couldnt paint my nails/keep long nails. But I was ok with it since I wasnt into manicures.But anyway I developed an occupational hazard after working on the job - fear of contamination and having to wipe, wash and sanitise things and wash my hands repeatedly. Before my contamination fear got bad, I used nail sticker sheets and would get so disgusted after I took a shit, because I felt that germs/bacteria would be trapped under my fingers. Or God forbid, actual poop. (Or in between the stickers and my fingers)I see a lot of girls with nice, long nails, and I would like to try getting gelish nails, probably short ones not long ones. I am thinking perhaps having short, basic painted nails or just short gelish nails would be good since there isnt a gap for the bacteria/germs/dirt to get trapped underneath my nails. But not sure if my fear of contamination would make me fear poop getting on my nail itself and having to remove the manicure, if you know what i mean. I am thinking...hmm perhaps a feet manicure would be the easiest. Sigh. ><Apparently, the doctor doesnt think that I have reached the clinical threshold to be diagnosed as OCD, hence, I dont use the word contamination OCD. But I dont see him very often and my compulsions are way more obvious to my family than everyone else. I use up soap bottles like crazy and I have so many bottles of sanitisers lying around. But my mum is going to keep her mouth shut because she fears that an increased dose of medicine would make me gain weight.

My (48f) best friend -not real name- Jack (59m), who Ive known for almost 10 years, has intrusive thought OCD. Since Ive known him hes been able to manage it with medication, able to let thoughts pass without having to check things, now its like he gets lost in his head all day and night. A little over 1.5+ years ago he started checking and rechecking things, sitting for hours last in thoughts, wasnt taking care of himself because he couldnt get unstuck. I‚Äôve been seeing a therapist, and they told me this. Thoughts are not actions; thoughts are not feelings. Thoughts can certainly cause actions and feelings, but the thoughts themselves are not indicative of anything other than thoughts. OCD can make you believe that your thoughts mean that you feel a certain way or make you believe that you want to take an action, but that‚Äôs your OCD. The thought itself was not the problem; the problem was the meaning we attributed to it. I‚Äôm not posting this to reassure anyone, but rather to maybe change the way you perceive your thoughts. Be kind to yourself and don‚Äôt let junk thoughts bog you down.

Or one chip. Or one anything. It drives me crazy. The other day there was one cookie left, and I loved those cookies. Somebody said: Would you like that cookie?. But I turned it down. Because I cant eat just one cookie. But darn it I wanted that cookie!Instead, that cookie stayed on the tray in the common room for a week until it finally disappeared. I guess nobody else wanted it either. I guess it got thrown in the garbage. I dont know the fate of that poor cookie. Whatever it was, it deserved better. It would have experienced love in my belly.I love grapes. I eat tons of grapes. I always take two at a time, and eat both of them. Because I cant eat just one. Because eating just one would something something bad day. Im sure you understand.Now its getting to a point where I eat two every time. So now two grapes has become one handful. I cant eat just one handful, even though its two, because its still just one. So now it ends up meaning I always have to eat four at a time (two handfuls of two).At parties when they are passing around the chips Ill grab two, eat them, and then quickly grab a second handful of two chips before the bowl moves to the next person. The chip passer at the party is always like, oh, you like these chips eh?. I dont like chips. But then I tell them I do. And we invariably start an asinine conversation about chips. Then they keep offering me chips throughout the evening. And I keep doing my double handfuls. They seem happy Im happy with grabbing multiple chips.Lol. At least at this point I can laugh at myself. Its so ridiculous. Welcome to my life.

So I just had a really difficult therapy session. One of the things I struggle with most with my ocd is respecting when people don‚Äôt want to give me reassurance for something. Hello everyone i‚Äôm a 23 year old female with anxiety and now OCD. I‚Äôve suspected I‚Äôve had OCD literally since I was a child, but a previous therapist told me I just had anxiety so I wrote off any concerns. My earliest memory of having OCD was walking home from school when I was 12, and I was listening to thoughts about having to go back and touch a pole 12 times. Aside from this I‚Äôve always had some sensory issues, now have many compulsions, constant intrusive and negative thoughts, insomnia, black & white thinking, struggles with spontaneity and generally just a awkward anxiety ball of a human. I often wondered if I had autism but come to learn OCD and Autism have lots of similarities. Things are starting to click and make sense to me. Started with a new therapist who immediately noticed I had OCD and has called it severe. This disorder is incredibly new to me and there‚Äôs so much I don‚Äôt understand. But my life has essentially been falling apart due to it. I basically up until now have never tried to resist a compulsion. I feel like i‚Äôm being controlled and my life isn‚Äôt my own. It really affects my moods and my ability to function as a normal human. My therapist and I are working on lots of mindfulness techniques, as well as general things to help me calm down and relax. I got a OCD workbook that‚Äôs been helping a bit too. Unfortunately one of my biggest fears is medication. But I really do think I could seriously benefit from medication. My therapist actually focuses in bipolar and OCD and works with a psychiatrist who does the same, which makes me feel better. TLDR: I am just looking for some tips for dealing with a new OCD diagnosis, things to look into, your medication stories, what helps you function etc. Thank you.

I was diagnosed last year but due to a generally crappy upbringing and this disorder, I spend a lot of my days convincing myself that the doc was wrong and Im actually just desperate for attention. I was researching OCD for a paper and found a compulsions checklist that is used by some doctors for diagnosis (not sure how common) and I have about 90% of the compulsions at a rate of 4/5. Im not the attention-seeking liar Ive convinced myself that I am! Not sure if this is a win but its lessened a lot of my repetitive thoughts about how Ive fooled everyone (including myself) into thinking Im sick.

Recently Ive dealt with POCD and existential OCD, the latter being worse. I still struggle with it from time to time. Im on clomipramine right now which 100% helps, my intrusive thoughts arent nearly as debilitating as they were before but Ive also been dealing with a bit of derealization as well, which in my case says the opposite, with my normal existential OCD I question if things around me are even real, Im terrified of the thought we live in a simulation, or worse, that Im the only one in it. Since THOSE existential thoughts died down a bit, it made room for derealization, where I saw everything as too real as Ive always described it, Im sure others would say dream-like or even unreal but to me its like someone took my vision and made it 8K resolution/120FPS or something, after that initial feeling my vision seemed to go back to normal but now I get these intrusive thoughts saying that flower looks too real, right? and then I get back into that weird feeling of being off. Im sure this is just my existential OCD taking a different path but Im worried these thoughts will mix and Ill think up even more terrifying irrational stuff.(sorry for any spelling mistakes that I missed, Im working with a broken keyboard lol)

hi guysi had pretty severe ocd as a kid (i‚Äôm 22 now), often with moral themes. like i was very afraid of being a bad person. as i grew up i realized i‚Äôm autistic and it started to make more sense how i developed that fear/obsession. i was raised catholic so i was really eager to be a Good person, but then i repeatedly got in trouble for just being myself. i couldn‚Äôt predict what would be harmful to others or not. like, i would feel so blindsided every time my parents sat me down and told me i had been being rude. i never meant to be rude but i was treated with contempt and frustration as if the behavior was intentional.  i kept ‚Äúfinding out‚Äù that i was a bad person, and it always felt like having the rug pulled out from under me. so i developed this fear that to me is legitimate, and i started masking really intently for my whole life. i would (and do) obsessively monitor other people‚Äôs emotions and opinions, and build my sense of self around that. now, i realize i‚Äôm autistic and i want to unmask as much as i can (both because i‚Äôm too exhausted to keep masking and because i value authenticity and want to experience life the way that is natural for me). but being around people has become terrifying as i‚Äôm once again obsessively afraid that i will unintentionally cause harm‚Äî by offending someone, not reciprocating emotions to the extent that‚Äôs expected, misreading a social cue etcetera. sometimes this is all i can focus on when i‚Äôm trying to spend time with people. this has led to me isolating excessively. i don‚Äôt know if traditional ocd methods would help me because i feel that my fear is based in reality. i would probably offend and confuse most people if i let my guard down around them. i‚Äôm very sad and i don‚Äôt know what to do.

So Ive made some progress with my OCD lately. I managed to separate my rituals into concrete ones - regarding my fear of flying or getting injured, for example. And abstract - the rituals that I do out of habit, created over many years of OCD. Then I noticed that most of my rituals are abstract and its much easier for me to resist those, since there is no particular fear attached.However what I struggle with is resisting these abstract rituals that cause a thoughtless mental discomfort. And while Im okay with not doing a ritual I cant revert (e.g. throwing out the trash in the wrong way - I usually cant redo that, so luckily my mind just lets it go), sometimes it is possible to redo an action.As an example - I was playing a single player computer game and I did something the wrong way in it. Sure, I thought, I want to resist redoing and kept playing. However after three(!) days of playing I couldnt get rid of this mental discomfort of doing something the wrong way. The entire time I was anxious and full of doubt that Id need to reload from before doing that action and lose 3 days of progress. That made every game session not enjoyable at all. I ended up doing a substitution ritual to somehow alleviate that discomfort. However losing to OCD made it worse, now every time I play any game, I need to do everything the correct way, otherwise Im afraid Ill get this mental discomfort again and will need to reload and lose progress or do a more severe OCD ritual.How do you deal with that?
